description:
Tunisian authorities declared a closure of all educational institutions in the country, as Tunisia moves on to phase 2 of the pandemic. 

*Update - The original closure of schools applied to all private and public schools. On June 18th, Tunisia announced that Public school institutions [Kindergartens, nurseries, computer clubs and childhood clubs] are to resume normal operational hours and capacity. These institutions are also allowed to reopen their public cafeterias and serve meals regularly.

description: Tunisia imposed a 5 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew from Friday in two southern towns to help contain a renewed coronavirus outbreak. Since its border re-opening, Tunisia has recorded a major resurgence of infections. Tunisian government hopes that the new curfew will be able to curb the recent infection increase. For now, the curfew only applies to two towns.

Curfew imposed in Northwestern Tunisia. This decision was made on August 29, where Tunisian government is imposing new curfew measures in the Kef province after a record high rate of infections. The curfew will be in effect for 10 days and is from 7 pm to 4 am and goes into effect on Friday 4th of September.

Curfew imposed in Northwestern Tunisia. This decision was made on August 29, where Tunisian government is imposing new curfew measures in the Kef province after a record high rate of infections. The curfew will be in effect for 10 days and is from 7 pm to 4 am and goes into effect on Friday 4th of September.
Authorities of two northwestern Tunisian provinces announced a two week curfew due to the increase in COVID-19 cases. The curfew will begin on oct 1 and will be from 8 pm to 5 am.

Authorities of two northwestern Tunisian provinces announced a two week curfew due to the increase in COVID-19 cases. The curfew will begin on oct 1 and will be from 8 pm to 5 am and will end on 10/16
A new curfew from 8pm to 5 am will be imposed in the Capital Tunis. The curfew will begin on Oct. 11 and last for 15 days announced the govenror of Nabeul.
A new curfew from 8pm to 5 am will be imposed in the Capital Tunis. The curfew will begin on Oct. 11 and last for 15 days announced the govenror of Nabeul.

description: Tunisia enters the epidemiological phase 2, on March 10.

Tunisia officially enters the epidemiological phase 3, announced by Prime minister Elyes Fakhfakh March 13.
The purpose of Phase 3 is to manage the consequences of the epidemic in the best possible conditions and to mitigate their effects. This stage is characterized by the circulation of the virus throughout the territory. The organization plans to mobilize the health system, as well as medical establishments to protect populations at risk, ensure the care of non-serious patients in their places of residence, and patients with signs of seriousness care establishment. Collective activities are strongly affected.

The director general of basic health care, Chokri Hamouda, said in the morning of Tuesday March 24, 2020, that Tunisia has partly adopted phase 4 procedures, which require the closure of the highly contaminated areas.
Suspend the exchange of students and student delegations abroad, unless absolutely necessary, while taking the necessary health precautions from March 4th.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The original measures plan also included orders to maintain all flights to Malta at the rate of three weekly flights and maintaining the traffic of freight transport vessels, while respecting preventive measures, in particular the prohibition for all crews to leave the vessels when they moor in Tunisian ports.

description:
Tripoli, March 15, 2020 – "The UN-recognised government [...] said it will close from Monday land borders under its control in the west to keep out the coronavirus. The Tripoli-based Government of National Accord (GNA) said air links would also be suspended"

"GNA head Fayez al-Sarraj made the announcement that [...] 'All land borders and air space will be closed for three weeks starting from Monday'" 

"will affect the border with Tunisia and the suspension of flights from the city of Misrata, both in the west."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Suspension of all maritime crossings between Tunisia and Italy, limiting itself to a single crossing between Tunisia and France, Tunis / Marseille, instead of two. Suspension of flights to Italy, except to Rome and reduction of the number of flights from 14 to 3 only per week.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Transport announces March 17th, the suspension of all flights to and from Tunisian airports. Exceptions made for air cargo flights, transit flights, official flights, and evacuation flights which are subject to prior authorization from the services of the Directorate General of Civil Aviation. All travellers arriving are required to comply with quarantine procedures.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The head of government, Elyes Fakhfakh announced Monday March 16th, that in four days from the announcement, there will be a total closure of the air and land borders, in prevention of the coronavirus. The last (air cargo-, transit-, official-, and Evacuation-) flights will until 20/04/2020 until 23:59.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
The government closed Tunisia's maritime borders, suspended all flights to and from Italy, in addition to reducing flights with Egypt, Germany, Britain and France.

*Update - Tunisia has declared that it will be reopening its external borders from June 27, after 'four months of self-containment ... in order to revive its economy and tourism industry in particular'.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The government closed Tunisia's maritime borders, suspended all flights to and from Italy, in addition to reducing flights with Egypt, Germany, Britain and France.
*Update - Tunisia has officially reopened its air and sea borders on June 27. This decision was made in an effort to revive the failing tourism that was impacted by the COVID-19 crisis. No date has been set to the reopening of land borders as of now.  Health measures for tourists and expatriates are set and awaiting implementation.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tunisian travelers and their foreign spouses will be exempt from the health requirement of submitting an RT_PCR test at the airport. This measure applies to states where the spread of COVID-19 is not critical, but average. Additionally, children under the age of 12 will be exempt from submitting to testing at airports.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Installation of fever screening by thermal cameras at the entrance to all airports and at sea and land entry points, intended for passengers at risk; from 22/01/2020.
Suspected cases will be followed up in the airport isolation unit for appropriate medical follow-up and sampling and diagnostic tests.
Travelers from risk areas who are non-pyretic at the time of screening, will be actively monitored by telephone for 14 days following the date of departure from the zones at risk, made aware of preventive measures and informed of the need to keep their home and to contact emergency medical services in case of any symptoms.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Strengthening of collaboration with the Office of Civil Aviation and Airports and airlines for the management of cases on board aircraft by the notification of any suspicious case and the identification of travelers from China and other areas at risk. This identification will be done by a dedicated questionnaire distributed during the flight and collected at the exit of the aircraft by border health control teams. The latter will proceed with the sorting at the exit of the aircraft.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Development and dissemination of an information sheet at the air, sea and land entry points for all passengers entering Tunisia, in order to document precise information on the travel routes of each passenger and their contact details in Tunisia . This sheet is available in paper and electronic format.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Transfer of all flights from Italy to same terminal, in order to guarantee that there is no contact between travelers from this country and the rest of other countries. As a matter of course the Department of Health has provided all the requirements for health monitoring at this station to prevent COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tunisia has turned to robots to help enforce its nationwide lockdown measures as the country continues to battle the global Coronavirus pandemic. The P Guard robots, manufactured by local company ENOVA can be operated remotely and come equipped with infrared cameras, which cover the robots surroundings, as well as a thermal camera and a sound and light alarm system. It is unclear which public official spotted their potential for policing Tunisia’s lockdown, but their presence upon the streets of the capital have provided Tunis’ locked in residents with a sorely needed source of distraction.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 7, the Tunisian Minister of Health announced the installation of thermo cameras at the public market of Wholesale Market in Bir Kassa. These cameras are intended to monitor customers and pedestrians and to alert health officials of those suspected of being infected by COVID-19.

Tunisian governmnet has launched a contact tracing mobile application that will allow the Department of Health to identify and alert users if they have been in close contact with an individual who later reports positive for COVID-19. The application will be available on May 19 and was developed by a digital marketing Tunisian company. Personal data will be 'archived for 14 days ... will only be used for contacting people regarding COVID-19".

The Tunisian government, along with the Tunisian Navigation Company, have announced new health protocols regarding maritime travel. The objective of these safety and health regulations is to minimize the risk of the pandemic spreading byway of sea travel. The protocol comprises of 'measures and procedures that have to be respected by all travelers during check-in, boarding, and during their stay on the ships'. These measures were inspired by rules and instructions sanctioned by the International Maritime Organization and the World Health Organization. These measures are to be followed effective June 27.

Tunisian Ministry of Health as well as the Ministry of Energy, Mines, and Energy Transition initiated a protocol that is to be followed when using air conditioners in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The details of the protocol have yet to be released; however, it has been publicized by the Department of Defense, the National Observatory of New and Emerging Diseases and the National Agency for Health and Environmental Control of Products. This protocol dictates the cleaning methods that are to be used when employing the use of air conditioners in private residences as well as public buildings. This protocol was announced on June 29 and is to be utilized effective immediately.

The Tunisian National Observatory for New and Emerging Diseases was granted "permission from the National Authority for the Protection of Personal Data (INPD) to use the “Ehmi” (protect) application to monitor people subject to self-isolation, so as to prevent the spread of the COVID-19." This was announced on July 22 and will be effective for use as soon as the app will be uploaded to app-store platforms.

Tunisian Health Minister announced that asymptomatic carriers of COVID-19 must self-isolate in order to stop the spread of the virus. They will be able to self-isolate at home, provided their homes meet health protocol requirements. If homes do no meet the necessary standards, carriers must self-isolate in one of the six mandatory lockdown centers.

Tunisian Chief of Staff to the president has announced on March 26 that 7 laboratories will now carry out tests for Covid-19. These laboratories will be able to carry out 10 thousand tests over a period of 2 weeks, which was not previously possible as only one hospital had the capacity to run tests.
Tunisia begins the local manufacturing of Hydroxychloroquine,  the controversial drug treatment for COVID-19. Production began on April 10, and will be distributed to all health and medical centers.

Tunisian government has rolled out an intelligence robot, Jasmin, that will assist medical and hospital staff at the COVID-19 unit. The robot's main mission will be to reduce and streamline the workload of the staff and minimize COVID-19 patient-personnel interaction. The robot will assist in triaging patients, take patient temperatures through its thermographic camera and diagnose patients upon arrival. The robot will also assist doctors in the monitoring of patient conditions and make no-contact diagnoses.
The establishment of a sanitary confinement in certain region that are classified as 'hot spots' with a total case number exceeding 250 cases per 100,000 inhabitants.
On November 30th, Tunisia demanded the acquisition of 5 millions of vaccines against the coronavirus.

The government of Tunisia has made COVID-19 testing available to the general public, starting in June. 
The test was not previously publicly available, but as of June the test will be made available post prescription submission.

Tunisia's Gabes commercial port's harbour mastor's office decided to generalise the sanitary control on all the cargo ships in harbour before entering the port, as part of prevention against COVID-19. "If contamination is suspected, the person is placed in isolation in the ship. The authorities concerned shall be immediately informed of any cases, in accordance with the instructions of the Health Ministry." These measures will be practiced until informed otherwise.

On 3/12, the Tunis Transport Company (Transtu) started a new sanitation procedure towards " its fleet of buses and wagons of the different lines, within the framework of the national plan to fight against Covid-19." The sanitation operation will be conducted daily and until further notice.
Suspend the exchange of students and student delegations abroad, unless absolutely necessary, while taking the necessary health precautions from March 4th.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: ON March 20th, Tunisian President announced that there will be restriction on the public internal movement of people, where city-to-city travel will be banned effective immediately and until further notice
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
The director general of basic health care, Chokri Hamouda, said in the morning of Tuesday March 24, that Tunisia has partly adopted phase 4 procedures, which require the closure of the highly contaminated areas.

Chokri Hamouda said that the name “cluster” is given to the area where a positive case is registered in a person who has not left Tunisian territory and who has no direct link with a contaminated person.

Chokri Hamouda stressed that the measures of the fourth phase are to close the contaminated areas and prevent their inhabitants from leaving the surroundings.

The director general of health care called on residents of affected areas to stay at home.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Tunisia is restricting travel between governorates from October 28th to November 8th for everyone except for need for work, justified cases and students).

Tunisia announces the closure of public and national parks, cafes, bars and restaurants. Education facilities will be suspended and mosques will be closed. This closure will be effect until April 4 or further notice.

Tunisia announces the closure of public and national parks, cafes, bars and restaurants. Education facilities will be suspended and mosques will be closed. This closure will be effect until April 4 or further notice. 

* Update - Policy was intended to end on April 4. Tunisian government just announced the re-opening of urban public parks as of June 16. Individuals are asked to respect 'health regulations in force and to comply with prevention measures when out in public'.

On March 20th, The Ministry of Health announced "the general confinement will enter into force Sunday, March 22 and will extend until Saturday, April 04 next." "Total containment means that citizens can only leave their homes in the event of an essential race or for a necessity such as the purchase of medicines or food."

"Total containment means that citizens can only leave their homes in the event of an essential race or for a necessity such as the purchase of medicines or food." 
*Update - Tunisia will extend a lockdown to contain the spread of the coronavirus by two weeks to April 19, the presidency said in a statement on Tuesday.

"Total containment means that citizens can only leave their homes in the event of an essential race or for a necessity such as the purchase of medicines or food." 
*Update - The Tunisian government extends nationwide period of general confinement until May 3rd

On March 20th, The Ministry of Health announced "the general confinement will enter into force Sunday, March 22 and will extend until Saturday, April 04 next." "Total containment means that citizens can only leave their homes in the event of an essential race or for a necessity such as the purchase of medicines or food." 
*Update: on May 5th, The Tunisian authorities indicated that the gradual lifting of lockdown could be reversed in the event of a second wave of virus infections. Tunisia started the first stage of the national strategy for a partial lifting of lockdown which includes three phases: from May 4 to 24, from May 24 to June 4, and from June 4 to 14.

A free number to the Emergency medical services (190) is made available to the community for information and reporting of symptoms. Another toll-free number (80 10 19 19) is available to anyone wishing to inquire about the measures taken by Tunisia.

description: On the 4th of April, Tunisian parliament has ceded some of its powers to the Tunisian Prime Minister for two months in response to COVID-19. The decision, which was supported by all political parties, will enable the Prime Minister to 'issue decrees, strike purchasing agreements, and seek finance without consulting parliament".

type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers

description: The Tunisian government has agreed to establish a scientific council to fight the COVID-19 pandemic. Tunisian health sources revealed that the council will coordinate their scientific efforts and medical research as well be able to compare results and findings. The council will be overseen by the President of Tunisia personally; primarily because, the council will be able to focus on border crossings and their affect on the spread of the infection. No date on when the council will be formally established.

Ministry of Health calls to carry out training actions for officials and executives of other ministries (education, higher education, transport, etc.) in order to contribute to the awareness-raising effort to combat COVID-19 in Tunisia from March 4th.

Intensification of media and awareness campaigns to raise awareness of the importance of quarantine adherence for travelers returning from at-risk areas, with the aim of ensuring the inclusion of all in the national plan to fight COVID -19. From March 4th.

The Ministry of Religious Affaires invites citizens to respect the health and regulatory measures issued by the Ministry of Health, as it invites imams to shorten their sermons and reduce the time between the call to prayer and prayer. The Ministry also calls on citizens to do their ablutions at home before going to the mosque and to bring their own prayer mat. March 11th.

description:
Tunisia implements quarantine policies for passengers arriving from risk countries. Implemented 11/03/2020.
*Update - Tunisia has announced it will be ending the mandatory quarantine for Tunisian that have been abroad and that are returning from abroad. Previously, Tunisian expats were forced to quarantine in hotels on their own expense. The government will instead request test results that prove the expats are free of COVID-19. Begging from June 18, repatriated Tunisians must submit negative test results in order to be allowed to go home.

description:
Immediate suspension of prayers in mosques, restricted opening hours for cafes (close cafes at 4pm every day), and ban of all cultural, sports and economic gatherings. 
*Update - Tunisia will reopen places of worship, restaurants and hotels from June 4, authorities announced Thursday, more than two months after closing them over the coronavirus pandemic.Hotels and restaurants, closed since March 22, will reopen at 50 percent capacity and authorities are finalising sanitary measures for tourism facilities.

*Update- Tunisia reopened mosques for prayers Thursday after a roughly three-month break. 
"As part of the measures, people wore masks and brought their own prayer rugs. Tunisians performed prayers at a mosque in the capital Tunis by following measures determined by the authorities.

The Governorate of Gafsa is to resume the rehabilitative construction of its railway system.
The construction of the railway, which links 4 Governorates, had been suspended for more than two months due to the mandatory quarantine period.
institution_status: This type of business ("Construction") is allowed to open with no conditions attached

description:
The Ministry of Women, Family, Children and Seniors of Tunisia has announced that inflatable pools are strictly prohibited. 
This announcement accompanies the announcement of the resumption of public schools to normal hours and activity. All private schools that are resuming their business hours, are ordered to not use any inflatable pools for students. Swimming in public pools is to be strictly controlled and regulated.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Tunisian Health Ministry has announced that it will be curtailing work hours for government employees to five hours daily in two shifts starting March 18. This policy will go into effect until further notice.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Tunisian Department of Justice has announced that until further notice, the Court of First trials, where 53 percent of criminal cases are first introduced, will hold remote and online trial to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission. Such trials will also be able to maintain social distancing. This program is the first step in Tunisia's goal of digitizing its judicial system.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached

description: Tunisian authorities will reduce working hours for employees in the public sector in order to stop the increase in COVID-19 case spread. This was announced by the Prime Minister on October 4 and the decision will be in effect until stated otherwise.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Regulated hours government services available (e.g. government services office open for certain hours only)

description: Tunisian President is granting a special pardon to 1,420 prison inmates. This is done in an effort to reduce the state's prison population amid the spread of COVID-19. The President additionally called for the prisons to be disinfected immediately. This policy was order on March 31 and as of this moment, is a one time order.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description:
On June 16, the Ministry of Health announced the closure of specific beaches, 21 in total. 
In order to maintain proper social distancing, these particular public beaches have been closed for the summer until further notice.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Tunisian Prime Minister announced that all public gatherings will be banned until further notice to reduce the spread of COVID-19. This was announced on Oct. 4 and the end date is still undetermined.

Tunisian Football Federation announced the postponing of the Tunisian league's new season until Nov. 6. The new season was supposed to start in Oct. 24 however due to the spread of COVID-19 cases, the start date has been postponed.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description: Tunisian Football Federation announced the postponing of the Tunisian league's new season until Nov. 6. The new season was supposed to start in Oct. 24 however due to the spread of COVID-19 cases, the start date has been postponed to November 27.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description: Tunisia suspended all sport activities and training as a preventative measures against COVID-19. This policy is mainly directed at Tunisian Soccer clubs, which is the main regional sport. Further preventative measures will be announced.

On March 15, Tunisian Ministry of Cultural Affairs has decided to close all of its cinemas and theatres as well as all public and private spaces that host artistic performances as a preventative measures against COVID-19. Closures will remain until further notice.

description: Implementation of general confinement with limitation of movement unless absolutely necessary or for vital services. Implemented 22/03/2020, and later (31/03/2020) extended until 18/04/2020.

Society of Tunisian Transport has announced that from March 23 until April 4, public transportation will be limited for public use. This is done in an effort to comply with the President's lockdown measures and to ensure the limited spread of COVID-19.

description:
Effective March 15, Tunisia suspended all sport activities and training as a preventative measures against COVID-19. This policy is mainly directed at Tunisian Soccer clubs, which is the main regional sport. Further preventative measures will be announced. 
*Update - Tunisian government has lifted former policy, deciding to resume all sports training activities and practices as of June 24.

Tunisian Health Minister has announced that wearing a mask is now mandatory. Those who do not wear a mask are subject to a fine of 120 to 5,000 Tunisian Dinars and up to six months in prison. Tunisia had previously been relaxing its health measures but a resurgence in cases has called for the re-strengthening of policies. This measure will be in place until further notice form the Health ministry.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
